description: Medium - The Conflict Deepens: Economic Grievances and Political Tactics

questions.question: How did the problem of debt slavery particularly affect plebeian farmers?
options: Patricians deliberately destroyed their crops to force them into servitude
The state taxed plebeian farmers more heavily than patrician landowners
Poor harvests or inability to repay loans could result in enslavement to creditors
Farmers were strictly forbidden from borrowing money under any circumstances
Debt slavery only affected wealthy plebeians, not poor farmers

questions.question: Why was patrician monopoly over conquered land a source of plebeian grievance? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Plebeians preferred to remain landless and pursue other occupations
Plebeians fought in the wars but received little land while patricians got most
The public land was too far from the city to be useful for farming
Plebeians lacked the knowledge and skills required to farm the land properly
Patricians controlled the wealth that came from land ownership and power
Land distribution was controlled by the Senate without plebeian input

questions.question: Why did patrician magistrates lack incentive to protect plebeians from creditors?
options: The Senate explicitly forbade them from helping plebeian debtors
Plebeians never asked for protection against their creditors
The tribunes always blocked attempts to protect plebeians from debt
Patricians viewed debt slavery as necessary for maintaining social order
Laws explicitly protected creditors' rights over debtors' freedom
Patrician magistrates were often creditors themselves who profited from debt slavery

questions.question: What was the strategic advantage of plebeian military secession as a tactic? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It involved violent rebellion that forced patricians to surrender immediately
It threatened the plebeian soldiers Rome needed to defend itself and paralyzed government
It allowed plebeians to take temporary control of the government and armed forces
It gave plebeians leverage without requiring direct military confrontation
It demonstrated plebeian indispensability to Rome's security and survival
It forced patricians to negotiate when they could not replace the plebeian army

questions.question: Why did the creation of the tribune office initially satisfy some plebeian demands? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Tribunes eventually became as corrupt as other magistrates in their own ways
It gave plebeians institutional protection and a permanent voice in government
Plebeians immediately rejected the tribune office and demanded something different
Patricians abolished the tribune office within a decade of its creation
It provided plebeians with power to block magistrates from abusing them
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Patrician Response - Containment and Concession

questions.question: How did the Twelve Tables satisfy AND disappoint plebeian demands simultaneously?
options: They established written law preventing arbitrary interpretation but codified debt slavery
They eliminated all patrician privileges and made all citizens completely equal
They gave magistracies to plebeians while leaving patricians with no political power
They abolished the Senate entirely and gave all power to the assemblies
They created equal voting rights but did not end patrician legal monopoly
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Limitations - What the Twelve Tables Did NOT Solve

questions.question: Why did the patrician strategy of making limited concessions ultimately fail? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Plebeians immediately rejected all concessions and demanded violent revolution instead
Each concession established precedent and proved change was possible within the system
Concessions created expectations for additional reforms rather than satisfying plebeians
Patricians refused to make any further concessions after the tribunal office
The strategy delayed but could not prevent eventual loss of patrician monopoly
Plebeians used each concession as stepping stone to demand more power
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Patrician Response - Containment and Concession

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the Conflict of the Orders'? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It refers to minor disputes between different military units and commanders
It names the fundamental political struggle between patricians and plebeians
It describes religious conflicts between different temples and priesthoods
It refers to disagreements among different regions of the Italian peninsula
It emphasizes that this conflict lasted centuries and shaped all Republican development

questions.question: How did Rome's constant external warfare shape the plebeian rights movement? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Plebeians' essential military role gave them leverage to demand concessions
It made plebeians less interested in achieving political rights and power
Wars were fought entirely by patrician soldiers without plebeian involvement
External enemies directly supported and encouraged the plebeian cause against patricians
Military success allowed patricians to distribute plunder and temporarily ease tensions
Plebeians could threaten secession knowing Rome desperately needed their soldiers
questions.text_reference: Section 3: External Threat and Military Success

questions.question: What does it reveal that the Twelve Tables actually CODIFIED debt slavery as legal? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It shows plebeians never really cared about debt slavery at all
It demonstrates written law alone was insufficient without political power to change laws
It proves the Twelve Tables were a complete failure for plebeians
It shows the tribunes successfully opposed and prevented the Twelve Tables
It reveals patricians controlled the legal code and used it to legitimize exploitation
It explains why plebeians continued to demand further reforms after the Twelve Tables
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Limitations and The Bridge
